text.front:
 
Prenat. Diagn. 19: 955-958 (1999)
Elevated Second-trimester Maternal Serum hCG in Patients
Undergoing Haemodialysis
Po-Jen Cheng, Ching-Ming Liu, Shuenn-Dyh Chang*, Yu-Ting Lin and Yung-Kwei Soong
Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Linkou Medical Center,
Taiwan, ROC
Prenatal Down syndrome screening with maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic
gonadotrophin (hCG) has become common. High levels of maternal serum hCG and low levels of AFP have
been associated with an increased risk of fetal Down syndrome. In this paper, we report five pregnancies in
patients undergoing long-term haemodialysis, all of whom had false-positive second-trimester Down
syndrome screening results. All of our five patients had extremely high levels of maternal serum hCG, but
normal AFP values for their gestational age, and all had serious complications during pregnancy.
